The short answer is: You'll have to measure it yourself.

A longer answer is: If you dispatch your work to a single thread in the background and the HTTP request processor waits for completion of that background thread (what else would it do?) you have just added overhead to your application

Please

  • measure if it has some impact
  • if you have positive impact: Inspect the impact that you measure and determine if the added complexity is worth to trade maintainability with performance

Or, more generally:

  • Write the code with optimized maintainability
  • Stress test the application until it breaks
  • If it breaks earlier than you expect it to break:
    • identify the bottleneck (memory, cpu, i/o, others)
    • fix your identified problem #1
    • continue at step 2
  • Congratulations. Your application serves the load that you expect and the code is in best maintainable state it can be to meet its performance requirements

answers.body:
I have a different view in the case of your tasks here can be run separately.

    // process something...
    // create and deep copy some object
    // some BigDecimal calculations
    // maybe some webservice calls

Can we run them parallel? If yes, then multi threading should help. You can create multi threads to handle different tasks at the same time to improve the response time. The requirement is these tasks should be independent from each other, or you are about make it worse because of locks.

But you are doing the same thing 2.5k times/second, you probably can consider if cache can be used to optimize the speed.

answers.title: Java - TileBased RTS Game - creating ResourceField as a DataStructure from Map
answers.body:
Since I could not put all this in comment, I decided to put is as an answer.

It seems like you’re trying to implement a flood-fill algorithm to identify clusters of resources on your map. Here is a simple way I would do that:

  • Create an empty list to store ResourceField objects
  • Iterate over each tile in the map
  • If the tile contains a resource and is not already part of a ResourceField, create a new ResurceField and add the tile to it
  • Use a recursive function to explore the neighboring tiles. It a neighbor contains the same resource and is not already part of a ResourceField, add it to the current ResourceField and explore recursively its neighbors
  • Add the ResourceField to your list

Some pseudo code:

List<ResourceField> resourceFields = new ArrayList<>();

for (Tile tile : tiles) {
    if (tile.hasResource() && !tile.isPartOfResourceField()) {
        ResourceField resourceField = new ResourceField();
        explore(tile, resourceField);
        resourceFields.add(resourceField);
    }
}

void explore(Tile tile, ResourceField resourceField) {
    if (!tile.hasResource() || tile.isPartOfResourceField()) {
        return;
    }

    resourceField.add(tile);
    tile.setPartOfResourceField(true);

    for (Tile neighbor : tile.getNeighbors()) {
        explore(neighbor, resourceField);
    }
}

answers.title: How to call a Java class from Java code using Runtime exec
answers.body:
If you want to run an arbitrary java class using Runtime.exec, you need a valid java command and to relay any output:

$ cat com/example/exec/exec.java
package com.example.exec;

public class exec {
  public static void main(String args[]) {
    try {
      Process pro = Runtime.getRuntime().exec("java com.example.exec.test");
      byte[] buffer = new byte[65536];
      int length;
      while((length = pro.getInputStream().read(buffer, 0, buffer.length)) != -1) {
        System.out.write(buffer, 0, length);
      }
    } catch (Exception err) {
      System.out.println("Error!");
      err.printStackTrace();
    }
  }
}

This should only ever be used by IDEs, build tools and similar. Java classes in the same program should never use Runtime.exec to invoke or communicate with each other.

answers.title: How to call a Java class from Java code using Runtime exec
answers.body:
So you need first to compile the Java class from .java to .class:

 Process pro = Runtime.getRuntime().exec("javac -d . com/example/exec/test");

then execute the .class

 pro = Runtime.getRuntime().exec("java com/example/exec/test");

Then read the input stream from the process

answers.title: How to call a Java class from Java code using Runtime exec
answers.body:
You can use my jaxec library:

import com.yegor256.Jaxec;
// This will compile the code
new Jaxec("javac", "-d", "com/example/test").exec();
// This will run the class
new Jaxec("java", "com.example.test.Foo").exec();

Under the hood, Jaxec uses Runtime, but also logs its output, checks the value of the exit code, and waits for the process to finish.

items.title: How to call a Java class from Java code using Runtime exec
items.body:
I would like to know if there is a way to call a Java class from another. I implemented a testing code as follows using Runtime exec, calling "test.java" from "exec.java", but the exec calling won't execute. What is the problem in the code? Thanks.

test.java:

package com.example.exec;

public class test{

    public static void main(String args[]) {
        System.out.println("Hello World!");
    }
}

exec.java:

package com.example.exec;

public class exec {

    public static void main(String args[]) {
        try {
            Process pro = Runtime.getRuntime().exec("java test");
        } catch (Exception err) {
            System.out.println("Error!");
        }
    }
}
